title: Chapter 2: Classes and Objects - Quiz
description: Comprehensive test of classes, objects, __init__, self, methods, attributes, properties, and magic methods

questions.question: What keyword is used to define a class in Python?
questions.explanation: The 'class' keyword is used to define a class in Python.

questions.question: What is __init__ method used for?
questions.explanation: __init__ is the constructor method that initializes new instances.

questions.question: What does 'self' represent in instance methods?
questions.explanation: 'self' refers to the current instance of the class.

questions.question: How do you create an instance of a class?
questions.explanation: Call the class name like a function: MyClass() creates an instance.

questions.question: What is an instance variable?
questions.explanation: Instance variables are unique to each object instance.

questions.question: What is a class variable?
questions.explanation: Class variables are shared across all instances of the class.

questions.question:
What is the output?
```python
class Dog:
    species = 'Canine'

dog1 = Dog()
print(dog1.species)
```
questions.explanation: Instances can access class variables; prints 'Canine'.

questions.question: What is a method?

options.text: A function defined in a class

questions.explanation: A method is a function defined within a class.

questions.question: What is __str__ method used for?
questions.explanation: __str__ returns a user-friendly string representation of the object.

questions.question: What is __repr__ method used for?
questions.explanation: __repr__ returns an unambiguous representation for developers.

questions.question: What is the @property decorator used for?
questions.explanation: @property creates a getter method accessed like an attribute.

questions.question: What is @classmethod decorator used for?

options.text: Methods that take cls as first parameter
Methods that take self as first parameter

questions.explanation: @classmethod creates methods that receive the class (cls) as first parameter.

questions.question: What is @staticmethod decorator used for?

options.text: Methods that need neither self nor cls

questions.explanation: @staticmethod creates methods that don't need self or cls parameters.

questions.question: What is __len__ magic method used for?
questions.explanation: __len__ defines how len() function works on the object.

questions.question: What is __eq__ magic method used for?
questions.explanation: __eq__ defines how the == operator works for the class.

questions.question: What does __add__ magic method define?
questions.explanation: __add__ defines behavior of the + operator for the class.

questions.question: What is __del__ method used for?
questions.explanation: __del__ is the destructor called when an object is about to be destroyed.

questions.question: How do you access an instance variable inside a method?
questions.explanation: Use self.variable_name to access instance variables in methods.

questions.question: What is the purpose of __call__ method?
questions.explanation: __call__ allows an instance to be called like a function.

questions.question: What does __getitem__ method enable?
questions.explanation: __getitem__ enables index/key access using bracket notation obj[key].

questions.question: Every method in a class must have 'self' as first parameter.
questions.explanation: Instance methods need 'self', but class methods use 'cls' and static methods need neither.

questions.question: Class variables are shared by all instances of the class.
questions.explanation: Class variables are shared across all instances and belong to the class itself.

questions.question: __init__ method is optional in a class.
questions.explanation: While common, __init__ is optional; Python provides a default constructor.

questions.question: Instance variables should be defined in __init__ method.
questions.explanation: Best practice is to initialize all instance variables in __init__ for clarity.

questions.question: You can modify class variables through instances.
questions.explanation: Modifying through instance creates an instance variable; use ClassName.var to modify class variable.

questions.question: Magic methods always start and end with double underscores.
questions.explanation: Magic methods (dunder methods) use double underscore prefix and suffix like __init__.

questions.question: A class can have multiple __init__ methods.
questions.explanation: Python doesn't support method overloading; only one __init__ per class.

questions.question: Properties allow controlled access to attributes.
questions.explanation: Properties (@property) provide getter/setter control over attribute access.

questions.question: Static methods can access instance variables.
questions.explanation: Static methods don't have access to self or cls, so can't access instance/class variables.

questions.question: __str__ and __repr__ serve the same purpose.
questions.explanation: __str__ is user-friendly, __repr__ is developer-friendly and unambiguous.

questions.question: Which are magic methods? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Magic methods have double underscores. regular_method is not a magic method.

questions.question: Which decorators are valid? (Select all)
questions.explanation: @instancemethod doesn't exist; instance methods don't need decorator.

questions.question: Which define comparison operations? (Select all)
questions.explanation: __eq__, __lt__, __gt__ define ==, <, > operators. __init__ is constructor.

questions.question: Which are instance-related? (Select all)
questions.explanation: cls is used in class methods, not instance methods.

questions.question: Which methods can modify instance state? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Instance methods and property setters can modify instance state; static/class methods cannot.

questions.question: Complete: Define a class
questions.explanation: Use 'class' keyword to define a class.

questions.question: Complete: Constructor method
questions.explanation: __init__ is the constructor method.

questions.question: Complete: Create instance
questions.explanation: Call the class name to create an instance.

questions.question: Complete: Access instance variable
questions.explanation: Use 'self' to access instance variables in methods.

questions.question: Complete: String representation
questions.explanation: __str__ provides user-friendly string representation.

questions.question: Create a Simple Class
questions.description: Create a Person class with __init__ that takes name and age, and a greet method that prints 'Hello, I am {name}'

questions.question: Implement Magic Method
questions.description: Add __str__ method to Point class to return 'Point(x, y)' format

questions.question: Create Property
Class vs Instance Variables
questions.description: Create Dog class with class variable 'species' = 'Canine' and instance variable 'name'

questions.question: Implement Comparison
questions.description: Add __eq__ method to compare ages in Person class

parts.question: What is a class?
parts.explanation: A class is a blueprint/template for creating objects.

parts.question: An object is an instance of a class
parts.explanation: Objects are concrete instances created from class templates.

parts.question: First parameter of instance method?
parts.explanation: Instance methods always take 'self' as first parameter.

parts.question: Instance methods can modify instance variables
parts.explanation: Instance methods have access to self and can modify instance state.

parts.question: Access instance variable
parts.explanation: Use self.variable_name to access instance variables.

parts.question: What does @property do?
parts.explanation: @property creates a getter accessed like attribute.

parts.question: Method decorators? (Select all)
parts.explanation: @instance doesn't exist; others are valid decorators.

parts.question: Static methods need self parameter
parts.explanation: Static methods don't need self or cls parameters.

parts.question: Class variables are shared by all instances
parts.explanation: Class variables belong to the class and are shared.

parts.question: Where to define class variables?
parts.explanation: Class variables are defined outside methods in class body.

parts.question: Define class variable
parts.explanation: Class variables are defined directly in class body.
